text: After the session, I had a couple of thoughts. I've updated my consent forms to allow for the sharing of data on OSF. What if a participant says they would like to participate but do not what their data on OSF? Does the participant therefore basically "decline consent" and you can't include them in your whole study, or is there some room to include them in your study but exclude that participant's data from the OSF share. Basically, if you share your data could you exclude a participant. I often think about this with respect to me, when I am participating in research studies. If you were doing a survey of graduate students in psychology at U of C it would be pretty easy to identify me based on my age and even some answers to questions (i.e., do you have children). So if you have a participant that would be more easily "identifiable" could you exclude just them from the data set or then you would make the determination that either your data cannot be shared or that participant shouldn't participate in the first place.

text:
Now there’s a conundrum! I think your course of action likely depends on the reason you’ll be sharing your data.

If you want to share your data so other researchers can reproduce your analyses in full, then removing a participant from the open data set but not the one you used to run stats is going to create different outcomes in analyses, which defeats the reproducibility goal. So if you want to make data open for this reason, I think excluding anyone who doesn’t consent to share their data from participating is a good policy. As a participant, you can’t pick and choose what parts of the consent form you agree to, so if they don’t like one part of it then they’d have to decline consent.

I’m less sure on post-hoc exclusions in cases where participants are more identifiable based on their responses. Assuming these answers are crucial to the analyses, you can’t remove them from the data set, so from a cost-benefit perspective removing the participant makes more sense. But then you still run into the reproducibility problem. Maybe in this case you should factor in the types of questions you’ll be asking (or behaviours you’ll be measuring). If they’re sensitive then identifiably is a bigger concern, in which case it might be more appropriate sharing the data upon request rather than openly. If it isn’t sensitive, then the impact of the participant possibly being identified is minimal, in which case making it open probably isn’t a big deal as long as your consent form was clear about what data you’re sharing. 

I guess it’s also the case that if the consent form is clear and a participant consents, then they will be aware and fine that they might be more identifiable than the typical participant. In which case you could just go ahead and share it regardless of sensitivity (at least from a contractual point of view; morally it might still be questionable).

text:
That’s awesome <@U01BMFWRAG1>, that you updated your consent form to allow data sharing!! What kind of study are you currently running?

I don’t have much experience with all this, but based on my basic ethics knowledge I’d say that sharing data that is identifiable is not great, even if participants agree to it. Singling out and removing specific participants also seems like a suboptimal solution, for the reasons Micheal mentioned and maybe because you would be removing diversity/variability from the sample, which we arguable already do too much in research. Maybe in this situation you could put in the consent form that no identifiable data will be posted openly (so you would remove all identifiable variables from the posted data), but that such data might be shared with third parties on request for specific reasons (e.g. article review, meta-analyses, re-analysis of your data)? Just a thought though, <@U01ABLH7DPY>, maybe you have thoughts on this too?
